If the flavor is created with "vcpus=2", the test fails because "rt" will be set([0]).

In the test below it would be possible for it to pass if the flavor only specifies 2 vCPUs because we don't validate the result of parse_cpu_spec() relative to flavor.vcpus.....but that'd be easy to add if desired.

My comment was not really clear and more of that I was talking about the test 'test_success_image_no_exclusion'. nova/virt/hardware.py.message: I don't think we want this, please consider my comment on test_hardware.py

a) This isn't a problem with the original code since extra spaces are handled already.  It's only an issue in the context of my addition.
b) This is a valid point, I'm adding a followup patch to add validation.
c) I would suggest that "mask" simply means "bitmask".  Thus "hw_cpu_realtime_mask" is reasonably interpreted as a bitmask of which vCPUs should be RT.  See for example the "taskset" command where "mask" is used to specify which CPUs a task can run on.

I think we have 3 different problems here:

a) to strip the mask which is fixed by your change
b) to ensure that when using RT, at least we have 1vCPU for RT and 1 for non-RT.
c) discussing about to use a range instead of a mask. From my POV if that was the desire we would have called the option "hw_cpu_realtime_set" but if that is the only problem perhaps we could use your suggestion...

What do you think about to push 3 different patches so it will be easy to review and discuss of them?

You mean the change in general?  Is the issue that we don't validate that the resulting vcpus_rt is within the range of 0 to flavor.vcpus-1?  Because if so, the solution to that would be to add some validation.

As it stands, there is an implicit undocumented assumption that the specified mask is an exclusion mask.  This is what I'm trying to fix, and I'm open to any suggestions on how to accomplish it.

In that patch you should just strip the mask, even if i'm not sure that should be done here. probably we need to strip any value added to a flavor extra spec.

The part you have added to support different kinds of "mask" should be proposed in a separate patch.

I understand that parse_cpu_spec() is going to strip the mask anyway.

My point is I think we should fix Nova to strip values added in flavor extra-specs instead of having a lot of 'strip()' everywhere. The other point is that I don't think we want the line 1260, we want only a mask on the set of the guest vCPUs.

That is why I asked you to put that patch at the end of the serie.

Basically I think firstly we should fix Nova to strip every values added in extra-spec, then fix the validation of the mask to ensure that at least there is 1vCPU for best effort and then think about your proposal.

I've moved the validation check to come before this...there's no reason for the validation code to depend on the stripping of extra-spec values.

I suppose it could make sense for this patch to come after any global strip-extra-spec-values patch in order to avoid adding the strip here and then removing it again.  On the other hand we'll have to remove a number of calls to strip() so what's one more...

As for line 1260, I don't think it's at all obvious to end users that there is an implied "all cpus are realtime, so exclude the ones you want to be non-realtime".  To me "hw:cpu_realtime_mask" looks like it should mean "specify the bitmask of the vCPUs that you want to be realtime".

It is exactly analogous to the "taskset" command where you specify a bitmask of CPUs for a task to run on, or /proc/irq/0/smp_affinity which is a bitmask of which CPUs an interrupt can be handled on.

If we wanted it to mean "exclude the cpus you want to be non-realtime" then it should have been named "hw:cpu_realtime_exclusion_mask".
I would say it's better to fix the current implementation before to add more complexity.
Can I get a review of the validation patch?  That should be uncontroversial.

This code needs to strip the mask to see if it starts with "^" in order to decide how to handle it.

parse_cpu_spec() already strips everything internally so there's no need to strip the mask that we pass it.  This *is* the patch to support different kinds of "mask".
The mask should be confined to the set of vCPUs, that set of vCPUs should *only* be provided by Nova. The only have the possibility to apply on mask on that set.

we change the syntax a little here. But I think those are invalid syntax. Like the flavor(vcpus=3), the user set mask as "0-1", but the user got all the vcpus as realtime. so it is more like a bug. So we are good to change this.

tools/gate/playbooks/vars.yaml.message: Just wondering, why did we increase these - were we running out of space @ 5gb?

though kinda moot here, as these should def not be enabled by default, we should make the devices small enough to fit on the hosts - its gonna be very hard to triage issues if we are running out of space on the hosts themselves.

It should also be noted that the disc layout varies by provider, so it may make sense to account for this - and auto format/mount at /var/lib/isici-loopback if required.

that's a good point.  while we need these things to be big enough to store whatever the client subsystem's tests will put in them, there's no particular reason for them to be a lot bigger.  in this case, it's hard to imagine, say, the mariadb databases on the gates reaching 10G, so it should be safe to shrink these way down (though by the same token, it's hard to imagine a case where they'd be sufficiently allocated to actually fill a gate's disk.)

they were actually reduced in v40 because they were running the fedora gates out of space, but that was because of a targetcli bug that was causing the backstores to not be sparsely allocated.  That bug is worked around with this change, so there's no need to have them be small -- because they're sparse, the actual disk usage is tiny.

neutron/services/externaldns/drivers/des.message: pep8: E501 line too long (83 > 79 characters)
Yes, will fix in next iteration.
Why don't you use the admin_client?
Ok, I think I understand now.

The "admin" client in a normal deployment doesn't actually have admin powers, so it cannot use the "all-projects" option. I tried that in an earlier iteration. It is just a unique client used to handle the PTR zones. Maybe we could rename it to something less confusing, but that would be unrelated. And changing the deployment requirements doesn't seem necessary as the current solution does work fine it seems.

Also note that we cannot figure out whether the all-projects option is valid during client creation, it will only fail later when an actual zone or recordset operation is performed.

I have 2 questions about that:

1. Why do we need first to try to delete it with "regular" user? Can't we just use this "all_projects_client" always?

2. I'm not sure if I really understand the problem. From LP I understood that regular user (say "user_1") creates server and then dns record is created the zone which belongs to user_1's tenant. And if then such server will be deleted by admin user (so user who has got privilege to see and delete not own server for example), why it can't see this zone in Designate?

> 1. Why do we need first to try to delete it with "regular" user?
 > Can't we just use this "all_projects_client" always?

No, the "all-projects" option can only be used by an admin, it fails with an error for a normal client.

 > 2. I'm not sure if I really understand the problem. From LP I
 > understood that regular user (say "user_1") creates server and then
 > dns record is created the zone which belongs to user_1's tenant.
 > And if then such server will be deleted by admin user (so user who
 > has got privilege to see and delete not own server for example),
 > why it can't see this zone in Designate?

It can see that zone only when adding the "all-projects" option to the query. This is similar to a "server list"which  will only list servers in the admin project even for an admin, they need to run "server list --all-projects" in order to see every server.

The one thing that I agree is a bit strange in the designate interface is that this is an option on client creation, not for the actual query, which makes handling this rather clumsy. One can successfully create an all_projects_client even for a normal user, but it will fail on the first query executed. Thus my approach here is to only try this once the "normal" client has failed.
+1 Thanks for the explanation in IRC

specs/train/encrypt_kek_with_client_indi.message:
I'm trying to understand this use case.  You seem to be trying to solve a situation where the client does not trust barbican -- or does not want barbican to see the secret.

Therefore you end up wrapping the KEK with a client public key, making the secret undecryptable by barbican, and requiring the client to do some extra work on decryption.

This presumably makes the secrets stored this work not useful to other openstack services unless they somehow also have the client private key.

Wouldn't it be easier to pre-encrypt the secret with the client public key, and then store the encrypted secret in barbican in the regular way?  That way, the secret is never exposed to barbican at all.

I guess I still don't understand why folks would want to use to use this mechanism, instead of just pre-encrypting the secret on the client side before sending it to barbican.

By pre-encrypting, you ensure that the secret is never in the clear, and you can even use simple crypto in the barbican backend.  It doesn't matter because everything is pre-encrypted. 

Pre-encrypting in the client solves all the problems you mention above, and is simpler, in that no changes are needed in barbican.

I'm not opposed to your mechanism.  I'm just trying to understand when folks would use it over pre-encryption, given that the client needs access to the private key in both cases to decrypt the secret.

The background is:
One challenge in current cloud computing is, how to prevent cloud service providers like Amazon/MS/Google and malicious software in cloud from sniffing tenant's secrets like crypto keys, as theoretically, host can get everything running in guest, this is why lots of HW/SW security technologies are introduced, like intel SGX, TME(total memory encryption), KPT(key protection technology),AMD SEV(Secure Encrypted Virtualization), ARM trust zone, tenant needs a trust environment to do the secret “pre-encryption” work.
If tenant do the pre-encryption work on compute node, then an obvious security hole dose exist, and on the other hand, it's not convenient for users who do not have crypto knowledge, as at least, they need a secret encryption tool/system.
KMS(Barbican) is a good candidate to help on it, which is secure, trust and has good orchestration interface, tenants just need to follow conventional way, upload a clear secret and get a key reference in key provision phase. In run times, only trusted clients can make use of the encrypted secrets retrieved from KMS.

> I'm trying to understand this use case.  You seem to be trying to
 > solve a situation where the client does not trust barbican -- or
 > does not want barbican to see the secret.

Not 100% correct, clients still trust barbican, but have some concerns/considerations about the backend HSM, 
1, Security concern as spec mentioned, “Current HSM's access credential is kept in barbican.conf in plain text, which has potential security risk.” See
https://github.com/openstack/security-analysis/blob/master/doc/source/artifacts/barbican/newton/architecture-page.rst
2, Performance concern of a centralized HSM architecture, in key retrieve process, HSM should decrypt EKEK(encrypted KEK) first, then make use of a KEK to unwrap the encrypted secret, it could potentially become a performance bottleneck
3, Implementation constraints in real case, the cost of backend HSM is high per our market survey.
 

 > Therefore you end up wrapping the KEK with a client public key,
 > making the secret undecryptable by barbican, and requiring the
 > client to do some extra work on decryption.
 > 
 > This presumably makes the secrets stored this work not useful to
 > other openstack services unless they somehow also have the client
 > private key.

Yes, this understanding is correct, only the clients which have the private key can decrypt EKET then retrieve the clear secret, clients have the responsibility to keep its private key in a trust scope, this requirement could be regarded as a limitation, but we also can regard it as a security enhancement from clients’ view, e.g. only the trusted clients is able to retrieve the secret.


 > Wouldn't it be easier to pre-encrypt the secret with the client
 > public key, and then store the encrypted secret in barbican in the
 > regular way?  That way, the secret is never exposed to barbican at
 > all.

1, We still trust Barbican, KEK is generated by barbican, and barbican will encrypted it with client’s public key, 
2, Yes, encrypted secret is stored in barbican in the regular way.
3, Secret is only visible to barbican in key provision moment, after it’s wrapped by KEK, it will never exposed to barbican at all.

1) the task will run on nodes where there won't be any nfs mounted, for example compute nodes if it is only glance configured to use nfs

additional notes:

a) leapp will reboot the node, hence we're guaranteed to cause service disruption already on this node

b) the fstab entry will be recreated and the share mounted later in the upgrade process when the glance or nova templates will recreate it, like it happens at deployment time

glance/values_overrides/tls.yaml.message:
Is there a reason for the different list of ciphers for different services?

Is there an opportunity for some more centralization for repeated values throughout all these charts?

This is only called out due to the requirement that ECDHE-RSA-AES256-SHA384; has to be included. However, I expect folks can remove this option altogether and still get a reasonable set of ciphers ensuring security. However, if folks want to further customize this (e.g. restrict things to TLS 1.3), they will end up overwriting this entire conf anyway.

Having helm toolkit spit back a set of fixed cipher makes it difficult to customize - and it will end up just reading off a key. Perhaps we can read this off {{ .Values.x.y.tls.cipher }} in a follow on patch set.

playbooks/artifacts/promote-deployment.y.message:
Those can be passed as options to the Ansible synchronize module:

 owner: no
 group: no
 perms: no

For v2.7: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.7/modules/synchronize_module.html




Note that those are set due to the module using 'archive' by default which is the equivalent of -rlptgoD :

 -r recursive
 -l copy symlinks as symlinks (equivalent of the ansible default "copy_links: no"). 
 -p, --perm preserve permissions
 -t preserve modification times
 -g preserve group
 -o preserve owner
 -D == --devices --specials, preserve device files and specialfiles

So potentially one disable the archiving and pick the wanted options:

 archive: no
 recursive: yes
 times: yes  # default is value of 'archive'

But that is less explicit than implying archive is on and then explicitly disabling the issue you don't want.
owner and group should be enough - and remove the comments. We have this documented under https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul-jobs/policy.html#preservation-of-owner-between-executor-and-remote

openstack-helm-infra/files/0011-Add-mari.message:
Why "else" ?  Is it impossible to have both  $envAll.Values.conf.database.config_override and $envAll.Values.manifests.config_ipv6 at the same time?

If the end user specifies a user override for  $envAll.Values.conf.database.config_override, won't that cause us to ignore the IPv6 setting here? That seems like an unexpected side effect.

Also, why are we not using the existing $envAll.Values.conf.database.config_override to override the mysqld bind_address?

If user specify a user override, he should consider ipv6 setting as well. It should not be an issue, since he want to use his own config.
Furthermore, Openstack-helm upstream not support both ipv4 and ipv6 so good now. 

We could not dynamically override config_override as I mentioned there is a problem.
If you have better proposal, please let me know, or you can work based on my patch, thanks!

Zhipeng

1)For the first solution, we can override it through system helm-override-update command, but could not use python plugin to dynamically override it as it will introduce a "-|" line in config file.
2)For the second solution, it refers to many changes on upstream and need further verification, we'd better do it in the future, or rebase the openstack-helm when it can support both ipv4 and ipv6 good.

Now I'd like to take your last proposal to add some comments in code and git commit message.

Thanks!
Zhipeng

It feels like the correct solution is to figure out why the existing config_override isn't working as expected, then use that to implement the IPv6 handling.

Another option would be to add a new $envAll.Values.conf.database section that implements a new ".cnf" file just for the IPv6 setting.  This would ensure that we don't conflict with the config_override option.

If neither of these are feasible, I would like to see a comment in the code here and in the git commit message describing the fact that a user override for conf.database.config_override will break the IPv6 system overrides.  I also want to see a comment in the git commit message explaining why we can't use config_override.  Basically, I want the hacks we're doing and the reasons for them to be clear to future developers that look at this code.

zuul/driver/github/githubconnection.py.message: This looks wrong since if exclude_unprotected is True we write a potentially wrong branch list in there.

The _project_branch_cache_exclude_unprotected and _project_branch_cache_include_unprotected caches are independent from each other and also filled independently from each other. So they don't need to contain every project, just the projects that are used in that specific context.

Project2 and project3 are not in the "include unprotected" because they were not used yet by a tenant that didn't exclude unprotected branches for them.

Regarding this change, consider exclude_unprotected is True for tenant A. In this case we would query the filtered branch list and store them in both caches. However the list we're storing into _project_branch_cache_include_unprotected is wrong because it needs the unfiltered branch list. After that imagine we're calling this again with tenant B that doesn't exclude unprotected branches. Since we stored the filtered branch list earlier it will get a cache hit and work with an incomplete list of branches. However without this change it would face a cache miss and query the branches as well but this time unfiltered which is correct.

According to [1] "include unprotected" should have all branches.
With a trace set here [2], we have the following log for TestGithubUnprotectedBranches.test_push_event_reconfigure_complex_branch (added in the parent change):

exclude:{'org/project3': [], 'org/project2': []} include:{'org/common-config': ['master'], 'org/project1': ['master']}

project2 and project3 are not in the "include unprotected" list

when exclude_unprotected is True, only protected branches are fetched [3]


[1] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/driver/github/githubconnection.py#L2130-L2137
[2] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/driver/github/githubconnection.py#L1444
[3] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/driver/github/githubconnection.py#L1460-L1461

deployment/tripleo-packages/tripleo-pack.message: Why remove this? It appears unrelated to me.

This is fine, but we could do this differently - we need to decide what the interface is we prefer? A shell script is infinitely flexible, but very clumsy.

We could, instead, have a parameter something like 'LeappRepoType' with the values ['subscription', 'satellite', 'custom'] or something like that.

'subscription' would use ansible tasks to make use of subscription manager (not shell tasks) to setup and enable the repo.

'satellite' would do the appropriate things for satellite.

'custom' could be a bash script for alternative (CI?) methods.

Any thoughts on that idea?

This is fine, but we could do this differently - we need to decide what the interface is we prefer? A shell script is infinitely flexible, but very clumsy.

We could, instead, have a path here to the location on the undercloud where the leapp files will be - eg: /etc/leapp/files

We could then use an ansible task to create the folder on the target and copy the files there.

This would be more restrictive in the implementation, but reduces the barrier to entry because no-one needs to setup a web server.

Any thoughts on that idea?

Is there still a need for this with the file copy process?

If this remains useful in some way - should the file copy and this be mutually exclusive, or should they both be used.

I suggest that we add 'checksum: yes' to the parameters here so that the files are checksum verified in the copy process.

Has this task been verified to do the right thing. Rsync is a bit funny and there might need to be a trailing slash in the src or the dest might need to be '/etc/leapp' to ensure that the copy is done right (with the ownership, selinux flags, etc).
Should we provide a default here using subscription-manager? The documentation can then suggest overriding the default if some other method is being used.
Well, I don't dislike this approach. In theory, the upgrade-prepare.yaml environment file is also a way to provide with defaults (and it will allow you overriding what you have there too).
Do we still need this? It seems like we already have another way to do the data copy now which is simpler.

I'm thinking...that if I am not mistaken, this command will run from the mistral_executor container. Which doesn't have the /etc/leapp/files directory:

 [root@undercloud-0 stack]# podman exec -it mistral_executor bash
()[mistral@undercloud-0 /]$ ls /etc/leapp/files
ls: cannot access '/etc/leapp/files': No such file or directory

So, we either map the /etc/leapp/files in the mistral_executor container or find another way to tell to Ansible to run from the undercloud node. I can do some testing for this and provide with feedback on the review.

Rather than pull this into the playbook folder, why not just bind-mount /etc/leapp/files,ro so that it's already in the container?

BTW, if you use the 'flat' argument here, it won't put it into the {{ inventory_hostname }} folder.
OK, that makes sense. I had hoped for something more elegant, but so be it.

But in line with what we are discussing here, if the user for some reason cleaned up all his leapp files or uninstall leapp, the /etc/leapp/files directory would be missing and this sync would fail. I believe we need some file existence check for the Undercloud first and if /etc/leapp/files directory does not exist on the Undercloud either fail with an indication: Hey! you need to provide your repomap.csv and ps-events.json files in the controller node. Tasks in this file, one_time_config_tasks.yml, are executed only once as there is a flag written after its execution (see its caller)
Yet, if ansible exists for any reason in the middle of execution (e.g. ctrl+c) then re-apply will delete valid data leading to data loss.

To avoid this case wipe should be attempted only if all lvextends above completed successfully:
when: item.rc == 0

same comment as above:

To avoid this case wipe should be attempted only if all lvextends above completed successfully:

name: Further resize if root disk size is larger than 240G
name: Remove stale data at end of LV block device

hmm...I will try without it again. I remember I tried it without 'become: yes' and it failed - but i forgot how the error looked like.

controller-0:~$ blockdev --getsz /dev/cgts-vg/backup-lv 
blockdev: cannot open /dev/cgts-vg/backup-lv: Permission denied
controller-0:~$ sudo su
controller-0:/home/sysadmin#  blockdev --getsz /dev/cgts-vg/backup-lv
41943040
you were right , Tee. Good catch! I tried without it and it worked. At the time it fell, I may have misinterpreted the error. Will sent out for review again . Thank you
Remove this condition. If res.rc was not 0 it would have not got here.
Never mind guys. I was a bit distracted by an issue in the lab :)

There are two case when rc!=0 on lvextend exec on a replay. In these cases the command will return 'matches existing size' or 'not larger than existing size'. In these two cases wipe has to be skipped or it will wipe valid data!
no, it needs to be checked with res.rc == 0 otherwise the previous task with res.rc!=0 won't prevent cleanup of the lvs repeatedly
